148817374.review: I played this series a couple years ago and just now 100%ed this game because the most time consuming achievement frustrated me for awhile.  While this game is not to my tastes now, I can see the appeal of the game that had me interested when I first played it.  It's the most well-developed game in the series and will take more than a few hours to get through (unless you're using speedhack).  My main gripe with this game is Evelyn.  I appreciate the idea that there's an alternate character to romance, but I don't agree with the execution.  I may be misremembering this, but to my knowledge, Evelyn is more or less Emily in a different font.  They have slightly different ways of talking and have different music tastes, but they are fundamentally the same person.  The game plays out exactly the same regardless of who you choose (except the endings you can unlock differ depending on who you first chose).  I don't see the point in having a second love interest if there's no real difference in story.  I also wish you could speed up the game without having to download Cheat Engine but that's not a dealbreaker.  Overall, I do think this is a good game if you're interested in dating sims and if you want to 100% it you should check out the guide that Ark made.

Once again, this game managed to immerse me more than most "talking simulators" ever have. In between the great nostalgic aesthetic, creative use of music (via YouTube, the only way teens did back then), and very engaging (if a little simple) teenage drama, I sincerely hope you give this game a try. Probably the best game in the trilogy.

It's direction is so clear cut in its execution, and charming from beginning to end, that it hits the emotional spectrum in all the ways a 2000s teenager probably felt, especially under the gaze of young love & easy-to-misunderstand online communication. Once I got into it, I really just wanted to keep going to the end, cheesy 2008 electro music and all.

And for someone who's never used Facebook, for your entire game to be you exploring "Facebook" and slapping random keys to type, that's pretty impressive. :)

144193606.review:
It's okay, although I do feel like the series peaked in Emily is Away Too, which I really enjoyed. The story for <3 is basically the same, just slightly longer, with more tedious dialogue options and exhausting drama. The choices and progress also get repetitive real fast if you are replaying for different endings and achievements. 

I guess the novelty of Emily is Away's interactive storytelling and the intimate yet relatable story would hit you differently if you've never played any in the series (in which case I'd certainly recommend).

Thankfully the nostalgia factor is still there, and it's probably going to be the most charming aspect of this game (as opposed to the story) especially if you're already familiar with Emily is Away games and their narrative style. Ultimately I feel like I enjoyed going through the characters' playlists and the curated historic viral videos on YouToob more than being immersed in the main story itself, just reminiscing about the good ol' days of being a high school senior in the late 2000's.

143360130.review:
The first time I played this game, it was so emotionally taxing that I didn't come back to it for over a year. 

I don't know how a game that's literally just pretending to chat with a girl over fake Facebook is so immersive, but it really is. The cringey dialogue, the in-game playlists, the references, the formatting, the fact that you can type IRL to type in the game... it all feels so REAL, and it makes the events of the game feel real, too. I never once thought I'd cry over a fake girl in a video game but here we are. 

Also worth noting that getting all 5 Major Endings in this game (necessary for 100% completion) is DIFFICULT. It's absolutely devastating to have to deliberately be an abusive jerk to Emily/Evelyn for 3 of the endings. Be warned: gameplay wise, it's a fairly easy 100%, but emotionally, it's the most brutal games I've ever completed.

142412071.review:
[h1]My review after playing the whole game with all the achievements:[/h1]

[b]The good side:[/b]

1. The sound, ambiance and all the atmosphere it's so good, makes you really think you're using a 2008 computer.

2. More than a game, it's a story where you are more than a viewer. This can be a good or a bad thing depending on the person that is playing.

3. Simple and relaxing, but at the same time you can feel all the feelings the story wants to tell you.

4. There's a lot of easter eggs that you can find if you search well.

5. Good characters [spoiler]I LOVE YOU MATTHEW[/spoiler]

[b]The bad side:[/b]

1. When you play the first 2 or 3 times it can be a good experience, but when you have 15 different endings and almost all of them with subtle differences, you will get bored easily.

2. If you're not into this kind of games, it can be easy to get bored, but this game it's a light experience.

3. Don't expect nothing more than a teen drama, but it doesn't means that is a bad game or bad story, but just that, don't expect nothing more than that.

FINAL SCORE: 3/5 ★★★✰✰

142410650.review:
The format and design of this Emily game is vastly different from the others because i resembles the early facebook days, so nothing like the previous two. It's okay for me i guess. The intro to this game is the legendary Windows XP one but when you log in to "Facenook" the cursor, while loading, resembles the one from Windows 7 (i was a Windows 7 user not that long ago, i can still vividly remember it). So this is a weird design choice, maybe the developer wanted to merge the two most remembered & loved OS's ever? Maybe.

There are two girls you can have a romantic relationship with, just like the previous game (except only the 1st one has Emily, the 2nd one introduced Evelyn).

There are 5 main endings and 9 sub-endings, which depend upon mainly minor choices, not the super important ones. I wouldn't suggest going over all of them since the game gets tedious after its 3-4 hours run. Too much typing and enter-ing! There is one achievement that requires you to get all MAIN 5 endings ONLY, not the sub-endings. If it didn't pop, go to secrets and press on the "5/5 endings" icon. It will pop up.

The main 5 endings differ a lot i guess but most of the time only the name of your girlfriend changes. After playing all three games of this series, this one frustrated me the most by far lol. Not sure if this was the intention of the game, but based off the other reviews written by other players and how difficult it is to get a "good" ending in the game, I wouldn't be surprised. Overall, this is what I thought of the game:

- The links that send you to a Walmart version of YouTube was pretty cool, you can even click on the videos suggested to you on the right, you can rate the video itself, and like/dislike the comments on the video. 
- Taking the love quiz and writing my own status/notes was cute.
- I wish there were more options for dating besides Emily/Evelyn. The game puts you into the perspective of a straight male, and as a straight female playing the game, I would often try to just stay friends with Emily/Evelyn and try dating somebody like Mat instead, but that just wasn't an option. 
- After playing all three games, the conversations start to become predictable or boring, so I had to take breaks in between sessions. I got really tired of being asked to listen to new music every time I talked to a character or started another chapter. 
- The endings frustrated me, I didn't appreciate being gaslit about being manipulative and controlling to Evelyn after asking her to tone it down with Steve since they were flirting with each other (at least they were in my opinion). But I guess this is supposed to simulate what a real high school relationship can be like, especially with social media, so good job to the creator if that was the intention. I also hate that Emily suddenly despised me just because I didn't go to her party (I didn't even say I was attending, I put down 'maybe' hoping there was a chance I could attend both). I went to Evelyn's party instead and she didn't talk to me for the rest of the game.

Overall I love the series, but this game just was really frustrating, and everybody else seemed to agree based on their struggle to get a happy ending with whichever S/O they chose. Just wish the story writing was a little bit better, then it would've been a perfect game, and I would've felt confidence enough to recommend it to my friends without fear of them getting fed up with the game (like I did).

First of all, I want to like this game and recommend it but I can’t. I will start by highlighting what I liked about this game:
- This game made me feel very nostalgic about my days in high school, where I would spend hours chatting with friends on social media sites about random stuff. The chat conversations in this game was quite similar to what I had with my friends. 
- I liked how the game had its own “YouTube” page with playable music videos directly from YouTube. Although the only song I know from the feature videos is the Metro Station song, it brought back memories.  Now what I disliked:
- The chat system. It was okay at first, but having to type every time after you’ve selected the text choice can be very grind and boring. I understand that the developers may have added this elements to make it seem realistic. But there should be an option to let players to skip this part if they don’t want to press random keys every time they select a text choice.
- There is no tutorial or anything that can help a player get around the game smoothly. I happened to have tapped “respond” to a Facebook post about my own death, this literally caused the game to RESTART. I basically had to start over from ZERO. The game is already very grindy given that you have to tap random keys on your keyboard every time you selected a text response to the other characters. It’s no fun having to start over, if I knew this would be the result I would have not clicked to respond to the post about my death.  Overall, I wanted to like this game and recommend it due to how unique it is. However, the mechanics and lack of tutorial is the reason why I cannot recommend it. It can get very grindy. Moreover, I read from other players that to get different endings, players have to restart the whole game; there are no slots to make new saves.

141720573.review:
It should be titled "Millennial Simulator." In no way is that a bad thing.

Somehow, I thought this game had more of a mystery angle to it. It doesn't, and I don't know how I got that in my head. But I'm glad for that mistake, because I probably wouldn't have gotten the game otherwise.

I'm one year older than the characters in the game. This game does a very good job of recreating how we used to use social media in that era. And not just the aesthetic, but the actual usage of the technology itself. Back when Facebook wasn't just your elderly relatives sharing conspiracy theories, and you still had plenty of friends without a cell phone- when social media was used to communicate outside of school hours because you didn't have any other way to reach some people. 

This works because that technology-based socialization that we cheered then and lament now is actually what drives the narrative and characterization forward.

This game made me feel a way that I haven't felt in a long time. Actual Facebook doesn't even feel that way anymore. Sure, I could look up songs or shows from 2008 and remember that feeling, but this game actually brings it back.

Is that just nostalgia? Maybe, but I think its something else as well. It's using the specific medium to communicate a feeling that no longer exists. Hence, Millennial Simulator.

141690315.review:
I played Emily is Away <3 and let me tell you, it's a trip down memory lane. It's a visual novel that takes place on a Facebook-like platform set in 2008, and boy, does it capture the essence of that time. As I controlled a high school senior navigating relationships and the impending college life, I found myself making choices that shaped the story and the friendships around me. It felt like every decision carried weight, as if my digital persona depended on it.

The game's attention to detail is remarkable. The recreation of Facebook, called "Facenook," feels incredibly authentic, from the scattered updates in the feed to the chain surveys in the forgotten Notes feature. And let's not forget the pokes! It's like stepping into a time capsule.

The story unfolds through digital conversations, and choosing between responses led me down different paths. It's amazing how a simple click can alter the course of the narrative. The game captures the anxiety of managing online relationships, and I found myself juggling various friendships and dealing with conflicts. It's like defusing a bomb, trying not to make a wrong move that could break a friendship.

What struck me the most was how my choices shaped the story and reflected back on the nature of my own online persona. It made me realize how carefully we curate our words and how easy it is to lose sight of our true selves in the digital realm.

Emily is Away <3 nails the authenticity of the era. The recreation of YouTube, called "YouToob," and the inclusion of cultural references and stylistic typos truly transport you back to the mid-2000s. It's a period piece that captures the escapism and culture of that time, but it might be a bit alienating if you didn't experience it firsthand.

The game's commitment to linguistic authenticity and the nostalgia it evokes make it a unique and sometimes cringeworthy experience. But that's what makes it so special. It's an embarrassing journey that celebrates the awkwardness of our digital interactions. And for that, I give it an 8/10.

okay.

i think i got this game pretty quickly after it came it because i love the EIA series a lot. i love the nostalgic feeling the series gives me as well as the pretty pixel art i get to stare at while i play! i'll be honest, the first time i played i was disappointed that no matter what my first playthrough was doomed to fail. that my relationship with the little pixel on my screen was doomed to crash and burn no matter how much i wanted to succeed. i was going to play again to get a better outcome, but then i realized i could only do it with my not favorite girl.. which is okay.. but it turned me off from replaying it so soon. it took me. and i'm not kidding. a year to pick this back up again, but now that i've played it again (and i'm sorry to the dev to reveal that i cheated to be on the right track to be with the girl i preferred <ev3) and completed the good ending i've gained some new perspective. 

i feel like coming back to it and revisiting the game and its characters the story felt more close to home for me. thinking about how the first playthrough is meant to fail leaves me with this thought: sometimes things in life just don't go your way. and there's nothing you can do about it. like with mat, he loved kelly very much but that didn't change the fact that they had grown to be too different and no longer compatible. but he still got a happy ending, just not the one he was expecting. i kind of felt like coming back i also got to have that. i don't know maybe i'm thinking/looking too deep into it, but i guess that's what i like so much about these games. i get to immerse myself in this little online world and forget about the real world for a bit. i get to socialize with these fleshed out characters and live a virtual life with them for a while. as an entry in the emily is away series i feel like this one has a lot of little details and content to explore and enjoy. i like finding the websites, the notes and the playlists. the photos the characters post. i've always been fascinated by the way EIA3 tells a story through social media.

in the next entry i think it would be really cool to have an instagram, or maybe an online clothing store to choose what to wear for certain events. maybe a spotify to make your own playlists for the other characters. there's a lot you can do with this format and if there's another entry in the series i'd love to play it. thank you for making such wonderful, immersive games!

139670378.review:
It's a really fascinating game. Just like the previous two games, the way that it builds rapport between you and the other characters is so interesting, delightful, and heartbreaking at times. The Facenook (basically Facebook) UI built into the game felt super authentic to the classic late 2000's. Even the webpages (these are REAL webpages that open up in your browser), even thought they're pixellated to high hell, teleports you back to the glory days of YouTube in 2008. I thought that the inclusion of Facenook as the main social media service was really clever, bringing in poking and giving pictures to all of your friends (and enemies) that you either chose to make or break in the game. Adding pictures for all of the characters and visually displaying the events with you and your friends that are discussed in the private chats drastically improves the immersion, unlike the previous two games.

If you want a game that will make you face tough moral and social decisions naturally in a late 2000's internet-style setting, then this game (alongside the previous two games) will be for you.

137592907.review: This game is absolutely amazing. And for a more complex visual novel, it's perfect. It sends you right back in time, it gives an excellent nostalgia punch straight to the face. It's filled with little easter eggs and references to 2008 media. The interactions are sometimes cringe-worthy, but that's also because it's supposed to be 2008, so obviously it will feel that way, and if you've ever played any Japanese VN, this will be no problem, because it's nowhere as bad. The immersion is there and it does a fantastic job of keeping it, for a brief moment you'll feel like being back to a simpler time, 15 years ago. 137498999.review:
Overall, the story is cute (albeit cringey, but that's clearly the intention) and I like the concept of it all going over facebook, but I have a few issues. For one, the choice about who you date happens really early... Like, you don't even know that's what you're choosing kind of early, so it actually just feels like you're being forced into a decision you didn't even know you had made. A lot of the choices you have for dialogue tend to feel like the same thing in the list you pick, but once typed out in full are drastically different vibes than you may have thought and you can't go back. If you were able to go back and pick a different option after seeing the message that would, in my opinion, be a lot better. The chapters are also long, and honestly sometimes really boring. There are times where you're stuck in a conversation that is kind of pointless and not interesting, but all the choices for dialogue are the same so you can't really do anything about it. 
Finally, and this is fully personal opinion, I would have broken up with my partner wayyyyy sooner if given the option. Or at least tried to communicate way sooner. 

I'm just generally not tempted to go back and play any other storylines, and for that I can't recommend this game. Going through one storyline is tedious enough.

133018752.review:
No time for a review so I give this game a rank C.
Okay game - not bad but you can skip it or try on sale.
See my profile for more details about my reviews.
Additional notes: so take these additional notes with a grain of salt as, admittedly, not only do I feel from a different generation as I am almost 10 years older than the protagonists, but also as a rather socially marginal person I feel even more stranded from the problematics the characters of that game live through.
So: Facebook? never used (I was an ICQ user, and AIM was for casuals). All the music they listen to? not my taste at all (I barely noticed some good stuff like Phoenix, but that is mostly it - pretty poor quality in general, though that is a subjective assessment more relevant to aesthetics analysis). The way they write, sms style, swearing every sentence, typing as if they go through a seizzzzurre each line, forgetting capital letters, punctuation, etc? miles away from my habits, I never understood that thing. Their school culture, prom, graduating, college, all that? from a country very differing from mine. And finally their mentality, bored teenagers, going to the mall, binging on alcohol, partying, grounded by parents, flirting with each other like rabbits... I always hated that as a teenager, and I did not get a tender look on that either as a grown up dad.
So what is left? Well, I had more hopes for the gameplay (with the web interface and all) but it all comes down to a very, very basic visual novel (say something, choose ABC, say something, choose ABC, etc) and choices do not seem to matter that much - the arborescence of choices feels pretty apparent, sometimes it is clumsy how the dev wants you to go a certain way. I also felt the dialogues were not very distinct from each other, like they all speak rather similarly, I would have hoped for the dev to ask a writer to model more distinctive dialogues to create more distinctive personalities. As of now, your girlfriend speaks like your best (male) friend who speaks like your other punk (female) friend who speaks like... a hiphop singer? It did not feel super immersive.
So after all, it could sound as if I only give negative impression, but after playing for a day on this game... it still made me feel a bit nostalgic about my own teenage past, about relationships through internet, and almost (almost) caring for the few characters K. Seeley invented. And making this game (caution: spoiler) [spoiler]not an actual dating sim but a breaking up sim[/spoiler] is a very unique take on the genre, with a different, melancholic tone, and that is to be praised. The effort is notable (all the fake facebook, the notifications, etc) and many people will find their adolescence back for a couple of hours with this game, so I guess that explains why so many positive reviews. I just wish there was more game than that, more in-depth writing and more stuff I could relate to - but on a "human experience" point of view, he still touches basic stuff from our teenage life, so I guess there is that. An interesting little game you might want to check out (I have not played his two previous (free!) games).

Listen, it seems like I have the unpopular opinion here since these games seem to be so well received.  But here's the thing:  It seems like if I'm a well-adjusted, trusting, supportive partner, my gf leaves me over her "we're just friends, trust me" friend because I didn't emotionally manipulate and control her into ending her friendship with him? And I'm not even sure what happens if I DO tell her she needs to cut him off.  I didn't bother to waste my time and go back to find out.  Does that make my relationship better?  If it does, that's not healthy, and if it doesn't...that's...also bad game-play because then your choices wouldn't even matter?  I wasted 3+ hours playing this game just to end up heartbroken in the end, and trust me, I didn't need a fake relationship in order to feel bad about myself. 

I initially had really positive things to say about this game because of the nostalgia and format.  I loved the original's AIM style text-based game-play and I love this one even more.  I like the old Facebook layout with pokes and status updates and chatting with your friends and the way it makes you feel like you're getting to know everyone.  But I just cannot get behind the idea that being supportive, trusting, and non-controlling is basically the reason I supposedly end up heartbroken and alone at the end of the game? 

This is maybe a little TOO true to life for my tastes, thanks.

The dialogue was incredibly frustrating as the love interest would get mad at you for little things over seemingly no reason. Even if you encourage her to make amends with her past friends and make new friends in her classes, she will later say that you don't want her to have friends and are manipulative, when in reality all you want is for her to not cheat on you, and despite her claims of not cheating (even though cheating to her only means not sleeping with the person), goes on to date the guy she was cheating on you with. In the final chapter, the conversation with your now ex is very frustrating as she continues to act like you were in the wrong to be suspicious of her relationship with her "friend" and seemingly tries to get back with you while she has a boyfriend. By the end of the game, you are left with virtually no one on your side as everyone sees you as manipulative for not wanting to be cheated on, which left me so frustrated. The game maybe could have been actually good or at least better, if the characters actually had any personality because then at least, the issues coming up would make sense and leave you frustrated in a meaningful way.

131744517.review:
I have mixed feelings about this game. I graduated from high school the same year as the characters in this game, so the nostalgia hits hard, and the developer did a great job at recreating Facebook and the internet in general from that time period. Everything from the music, to the kind of stuff that people were posting about on Facebook, even the dialog in the chat felt like stuff that I would have said or seen. Also, the characters feel quite real. They hook you in and get you invested in the story.

The problem that I have with it has more to do with the story structure, and can't be gone into without major spoilers. Suffice to say, nothing you say or do matters, other than at the very beginning when you choose which party to go to. After playing through the story, it felt very unsatisfying, I read a bit more about the game (specifically the community guide by Steam user Ark) and actually got a little mad once I understood how it works.

So in summary, if you were in high school in 2009 and want four hours of mopey nostalgia, it might be worth picking this game up on a discount. But don't expect to enjoy it very much, and don't believe the top user tag, which is "choices matter" or the developer's description where it says: "Emily <3 features multiple branching paths, unique conversations and different endings. All of them depending on the choices you make."

130977966.review:
It's a big enough game for me to know that a full review would be just a drop in the ocean of discourse so i'll keep it short, focusing on things i wish i knew before i bought it:

the bad:
--> This game is not worth the original price if u don't get payed in US dollars, wait for a better deal. It is too short for the listed price in my currency, and there are just better written visual novels worth the same.
--> It's a multiple choice game on which you cannot, no matter what you choose, to get a good ending on the first run. That's my main problem with it: When you do your first run with one of the girls, you will get the bad ending no matter what and unlock the good ending with the other one. That means that if you have a preferred character you have to play the game 3 effin times to get a good ending with them. I only did my first run and it was a little frustrating to feel that even though i did everything right it didn't matter one bit. So i recommend you find your fav and play a run with the other one first.
--> the writing is good but replaying the same run makes it really repetitive, which sucks if you HAVE to replay it at least once with the same person to get a good ending.


the good
--> The visuals of it are amazing and it is really immersive to jump back in 2008. The music and the YouTube layout from the links and the quizzes make it a super fun journey down through memory lane. I recommend taking an hour to play it and like, deep dive in it for each chapter.
--> The writing is fun, and the characters are supper compelling, which is just what drove this towards a thumbs up game. The drama is well developed and the conversations are wholesome and nice.


Anyway. That's that. I recommend it if you like visual novels, i recommend if you see it with a nice discount, and i recommend it if you liked the previous 2, as it is way better then what came before :]

130777378.review: Emily is Away <3 is a truly remarkable game that captures the awkwardness of growing up online with a sense of honesty and authenticity. The game is a visual novel told entirely through the ancient internet and lets players control a high schooler in their senior year as they navigate the anxious period of life where all permanence starts to fade. The decisions you make can have a dramatic impact on the story, with various branching dialogue paths and choices that can either make or break relationships. The game recreates the 2008 version of Facebook and YouTube faithfully, and includes references to music, memes, and cultural jokes of the era. It's an emotional experience that captures the nuances of online communication and gives players a unique window into the past. Emily is Away <3 is a must-play for 2000s adolescents and anyone looking for an authentic online communication experience.

130219479.review:
More of a 'meh' than a negative tbf but nearer -ve.

Earlier titles were much better, and left you with a lingering nostalgic feeling ('emily is away'...). I do wonder what people think of these games who didn't go through it firsthand?
The game does have a fair bit of nostalgia (the pull/crux of the series, along with navigating relationships to a point) but this game has a really questionable choice of mechanics:

1) You cannot get a 'good' ending on your first playthrough, there's a coded switch to only offer that on your second relationship goal/2nd save. Play as kindly or realistically as you like, you'll still get the a short straw til you try again. That's not satisfying, that's forcing replays :P 

2) It misses a lot of the nuance earlier titles had and feels a bit shorter but equally drawn out (awkward pacing). Choices don't really matter until chapter 4 which decides the ending, then chapter 5's choices the subending and in typical fashion, characters do some nonsensical illogical things based on their wild teenage emotions and you need to stay grounded or be swept up in it lol
 
3) You always have to justify your choices, especially if you want to feel like you've not just been interrogated by the NPCs who have themselves lead you down a path. You are once again playing emotional tugofwar with an NPC who always starts off open and excitable and can rip the carpet from under you - the female characters in these games are written to have serious personality disorders lol  It's amusing that these games enjoy imitating the social dysfunction of mid 2000 preadults (forgive us) but it's not always exactly an enjoyable experience as a game haha

4) The switch to 'facenook' doesn't carry the same impact as AIM (and being 'away'). Surprised they didn't go with MSN as that was more the bridge between AIM and Facebook. Now that was a time!

I would say, try out the earlier titles because it's clear the series is losing steam.

130065025.review:
This game perfectly emulates the ups and downs of high school relationships. It evokes those feelings of "first love" if you've experienced it. I found myself grinning like an idiot through a lot of the dialogue.

However, I cannot recommend it due to a certain game mechanic. 

TLDR: Spoilers, your choices do not actually matter.

[spoiler] It is IMPOSSIBLE to get the good ending on your first playthrough. It's in the game's code. No matter what you say, it will lock you into a bad ending. I feel this is completely misleading as the game advertises it self as "Emily <3 features multiple branching paths, unique conversations and different endings. All of them depending on the choices you make." If the game locks you into a bad ending, your choices simply do not matter. In order to get the good ending, you must play through the entire game twice, getting the bad ending for each girl. I simply did not have the motivation to play through it a second time to get the good ending.

I find this problematic as the player is left feeling either too controlling/manipulative, or too relaxed and careless. I've lived through this exact experience, and know that it's better to not be controlling/manipulative. I feel that if the player has the presence of mind to recognize this, they should be rewarded. I fear the young, inexperienced gamer may make the correct choices, get negative-feedback from this game, leading to them being controlling/manipulative in their real life relationships. 
  [/spoiler]

130017968.review:
A decent 3rd title for the Emily is Away series. It was great being introduced to the new social media of Facenook and being moved away from AIM.

The design of the game is great – has the same looks of the early days of Facebook and the story is probably the best out of the 3 games. However, it felt very much the same as the previous 2 games.

The story is very gripping, and I ended up playing through all the endings (mainly to get the achievement but also to experience all the different stories) and the writing is fabulous. However, even though there are two different characters in the game, both share the same dialogue. So even though the writing is great, it did feel a bit repetitive at times even though I waited  6 months between playing the game through the first play through and the second. And since I had played the last 2 games, it was very predictable as to what was going to happen next.

I also found it disappointing that during the first play through, it is impossible to get a good ending. You can only achieve this after you have played through the game once before.

The game can run on any laptop or PC made within the last 10 years which is great as anyone can play it however, I think the price tag of the game is a bit steep. I think if you can pick up the game whilst it’s on sale then it’s worth it, especially if you’ve played through the last 2 games. (You don’t need to have played the last two games to understand what’s going on)

Overall, I think this is still a good game to pick up, especially during a sale.

This game is absolutely gut wrenching, and it's a really good thing.

Gameplay wise, it's really cool that there were more characters than in the first couple of games, it makes the whole experience more believable. The interface mimicking Facebook with working links and the Youtoob pages really help with the immersion.

This game, just like the first two, made me feel so many emotions, from happiness to a deep, dark depression. I got drunk while playing it (as you do when playing these kinds of games) and I shit you not, it made me relieve all the relationships I had as a teen and early adult. You really feel like you're a teen again, the different options you can choose when talking to the characters are varied enough for you to answers how you would in real life in the same situation. The characters really distinct personalities which shows that a lot of time was put into writing them. 

I would recommend playing this game in one sitting as it isn't too long. 

On my first playthrough, only 4% of players got the same ending as me which surprised me. I really want to play it again, though I am not mentally prepared to get my heart broken by a video game character again this soon.

This game brings a weird mix of melancholy and nostalgia to the player, which is what makes it feel so personal. Sad and beautiful at the same time, both funny and heavy, creative and familiar. This game is amazing, it it well worth every second you will put into it.

128095299.review:
[b]This review does not contain spoilers.[/b]

This is not a pleasant review to write. Whilst I was initially excited to see a browser integrated into the game, and expected that external links have been incorporated within the game, unfortunately that was not the case; however, I have come to the realisation this likely has to be due to the omnipresent enigma that is copyright law. Provided this is the case, then that can be forgiven, but then my question becomes: Why not also create stylised derivations as was done for the rest of the game?

It pains me to say that although the gameplay itself was more enjoyable than the previous two games, this one was by far my least favourite of the trilogy due to its blatant disregard for my decisions during the first playthrough. It cannot be emphasised enough how distressed it made me.

The narrative also seemed to have regressed by being more heavy-handed than even the first game. My choices felt far more limited as if I was being told a story rather than being part of one, which is not in the spirit of games of this genre. As I continued to progress, I consciously found myself making decisions purely in the hopes that it would reroute the course I was being forcibly steered into rather than ones that would lead me in the direction I preferred. By the time I had finished the game, I was relieved it was over.

Timed events have been removed which I believe was the right decision, especially as we were introduced to an even more complex interface with many pages to shuffle though. As such, the type-assist accessibility option was utilised; however, the settings menu ever continues to lack an audio volume slider. The controls are exactly as you would expect from the previous two games.

Whilst I cannot honestly claim that it is a bad game altogether as there are certainly many players who will and do relate to the narrative far better than I possibly could, I simply cannot recommend it. It is not for me but I do look forward to the next installment in the franchise.

Follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43277557-Swyllikx/]curator page[/url].

127336497.review:
Note: a slightly lengthy review, to address one single problem and I wrote this at like 1am so there's probably writing errors that I didnt care about

I really want to give this game a positive review. I loved the first and second Emily Is Away games, but I'm giving this a negative review. Promise me, I wanna stress that I love this series, but I can't give it a positive due to one single problem. 

I'll start with the good aspects of the game since the main focus of this review is on the negatives. The game has more "innovation" compared to the first and second games. You can see in the first game, you are only limited to the chat box, the second game has TWO girls (not one!) and utilizes "links" that use your own browser (Chrome, Firefox, etc), but you're stuck in only sites that a character like Evelyn or Emily gives you. Which worked fine IMO, as the game doesn't need that much immersive action. However, this third one utilizes an "in-game" browser browse Facenook (a 2008 version of Facebook) but still uses your browser for other sites like YouToob. Other features included that more characters will come up and chatting with you (you can only chat with Evelyn or Emily in the second). Some notable character you'll talk about is your best friend Mat and his girlfriend, Kelly. There's not much else different from the other games that I can note.

Now the negatives, which I hate to say this. The main issue with this game is that [b]Emily and Evelyn are exactly the same[/b]. Like legit exact. Notice in the game's achievement, there is an "All endings" achievement. At the time of writing this, it sits around 1.5%. If you're a completionist, prepare for a boring grind for you. Most of the game's dialogue is the same word for word. A scenario happening with Evelyn, even if it's minor and forgettable, will occur with Emily as well in some way. One of the most evident examples of this is their (as in Emily or Evelyn) "baby" is somehow dead, which the character learns is that it was their iPod and you are actually their "babe." Here's a couple lines from that scene, 


"<33"
"what! oh noo :("
"I just tried to turn on baby and its deadd."

Emily or Evelyn will say this word for word in the game with *barely* any changes at all. Most of Seeley's changes for the dialogue are just reworded to "fit" their type of personality. Their profiles clearly shows the difference, so there are not a identical one-for-one copy. But the dialogues sometimes make them indistinguishable at all.

Despite all this, it's shown that in the second game, the dialogue wasn't worded for word. Evelyn is a punk who rebels and is all in it, while Emily is a shy person who seems to be taking her life slowly. They talk about the same things in the game but approach it differently. Emily and Evelyn have other plans for their future after college, and what their favorite music is. None of that is shown in this game. This goes back to the achievement I was talking about. If you're trying to aim for 100%, you're gonna repeat playing this game a lot with the same dialogue and repeating dating the same girl, almost like a chore.

Another big one is the ending. (spoilers) [spoiler]Your first ending to the game will always be doomed as the character you choose will always leave you, and the second ending may be a good one as long as you do everything right like a nice guy. I'm fine with that, as long there's replayability. It makes it more different compared to Emily is Away Too where people called it "the game where you break up for lying about your favorite song" due to how you can get a bad ending for just having different music choices and lying. So let's say you replay it. You picked Emily in your first run, so you wanna try Evelyn. After completing some of the chapters, it's clear that you say to yourself, "isn't she just Emily?" As I said in the previous paragraphs. It's a chore to repeat, even with different characters. You might even say that this paragraph is just a copy and paste from the last one but reworded to show Emily and Evelyn are the same because it all comes down to this flaw! So yes, I believe the problem in this game and why I am giving this a negative review is that it all originates from the problem. They are just the same two people. These two people are just the same. [/spoiler] If this was changed and was somehow like with the second game, I would give this game a positive review. But given how the first ending will always be, you're going to get bored on your second run.

I wanna end this review to question "why?" This wasn't an issue in the second game, so why is it done here now? I think this is lousy, and the jump from $5 (second game) to $10 doesn't warrant this. The Emily Is Away series have a unique storytelling and there's so much potential to it, but it always fall short on one part.

127134762.review:
Emily is Away <3 is the third installment of the Emily is Away series and is (Minor spoilers)[spoiler] the third time a girl named Emily broke my heart. [/spoiler] 

The game functions similar to visual novels where the story progresses linearly as you make choice dialogues when chatting to certain characters. Unlike the previous installments of the Emily is Away series, this game mimic the early age of Facebook rather than mimicking AIM/ AOL instant messaging. If you grew up around this era of the internet, it is certainly to take you on a nostalgic trip. 

Now the meat of the game is the interactive story and characters you talk to on Facenook (The in game version of Facebook). The characters you interact with all have their charms and personality that honestly replicate the feeling of chat messaging someone very well. Given that you can only send pre-determined messages that lead to pre-determined responses, it still works very well in making you feel like you're going through your final years of high school again.

This rings especially true when interacting with one of the main love interests, either Emily or Evelyn. As you progress through the game, you will progress (and even move backwards) with your relationship with them. The writing feels and flow very naturally, adding that extra layer of immersion that make you question if you're also starting to get attached to your choice girl. Because of this, this game can also create very real feelings in later parts of the games. You'll start feeling jealous yourself, heart broken, petty, irrational, all of this thing just as well as it makes you feel happy, content, butterflies, heart racing in the beginning of the game.

The only main criticism I have of the game is that Evelyn and Emily's personality seemingly merge after Chapter 1 which is a shame considering how different the two girls are. That and the [spoiler] Good ending is locked behind a second playthrough. I understand why you would want the player to experience heartache in the first playthrough as it leave a much more emotional impact but I wish that it was easier reaching the good ending without replaying the game. [/spoiler]

Overall, if you're looking for a emotionally driven narrative and some nostalgia on the side, I highly recommend this game. Fans of the series will already know what to expect but newcomers can enjoy this just as much. The price tag of $10 is perfectly reasonable for a game of 4 hours with this much emotional impact but if you must, get it on sale. This game will force you to live through your highschool traumas once more.

125508023.review:
Teen Drama Llama Simulator, circa 2008. [i]Emily is Away[/i] starts out interesting but its key mechanic, spam typing gibberish to advance the pre-written plot responses, really harms the impact. Strong suggestion here to have the on-screen keyboard up and running so you can spam-click your way through dialogue otherwise you'll be at this one all day.

This game's fairly hard to review without ruining the plot. Suffice to say it revolves around deceit and true friends in equal parts, with a healthy dose of amazingly bad period music. Amazingly bad as in I used to listen to some of this stuff...for some reason. Recreations of old websites lots of us visited is the best part of [i]Emily is Away[/i], the early Facebook knockoff being surprisingly interactive to the point it includes some lousy hidden Flash games.

A single play-through will run you about five hours, to 100% the game you're probably looking at around 20 due to multiple endings. All achievements work, many can be unlocked quickly via a Guide on the hub if you're not up for hunting secrets.

Worth a run through if acquired in a bundle, but otherwise I'd wait for a steep sale before picking [i]Emily is Away[/i] up.

124430962.review:
Over an hour in and I feel like I played the whole game. This is a slice-of-life game where you talk to your character's friends during their Senior year of High School. The dialogue with friends (which seems to be the whole game) is dull the say the least. I was expecting more drama, unexpected events, and a choice between a quicker or slower-paced run. 

The whole first chapter is simply just picking whose party to go to and that in itself took nearly thirty minutes (each chapter seems to be about 30 minutes but feels like 60). While playing my first run, I just wanted to pick one of the options within five minutes but instead, I had to read through the terrible dialogue. Which is the main issue...a game relying solely on dialogue...should have decent storytelling. Yes, the game does hit you with some nostalgia and memories of when Facebook was first invented but that isn't enough for people to have to read through the terrible dialogue. I found myself just picking options and just trying to get through the chapter because I found many conversations to be so uninteresting and seemingly never-ending. It's not very comforting that I am already skipping dialogue in the first two chapters when the whole game in itself is reliant on your responses. It would help if I could manually save the game instead of forcing myself to go through conversations that may end up being lengthy. 

I don't think this is a game for most people due to the simple storytelling but it's definitely unique and good for the sake of walking down memory lane for people who grew up during the Facebook era.

Lastly!! I have to note that on this page Steam has links and quotes of famous Youtubers on the Steam Review page! The quotes by these Youtubers are for "Emily is Away Too" NOT "Emily is away <3" That is a bit deceiving as they are NOT the same game.

124011842.review:
(Preface, I have not played any of the previous games.) Super nostalgic throwback for anyone who was in high school when Facebook was the hottest thing on the block. Everything from the UI down to the social interactions is dead on perfect. Characters and dialogue were well written and believable, and I found myself quickly investing in the story and the people involved.

I'm torn about recommending this game. On the one hand, the nostalgic throwback was enjoyable, the writing and the characters have a lot going for it. But on the other hand, there's a huge problem with the inherent game design.

The game forces you to play it twice to get a good ending. There are two romantic interests, and whoever you go with on your first playthrough, you are predetermined to fail your relationship with her regardless of your choices, and on your second, you can only succeed with the other. Which means, if you want to to succeed with your preferred girl, you have to either: 1) know a head of time to do your first playthrough with the character you're less interested in (or not at all interested); or 2) edit your save file after completing the first playthrough. (Save file editing is only an option if you made the correct set of choices on your first playthrough, as far as I'm aware. If you didn't, then good luck, you have to actually play through it again.) I went into the game blind, as I do all games that I don't want spoilers for, and was thus left feeling very defeated despite knowing that I was as decent a human being as I could have possibly been. Realizing (after looking at ending guides) that I could edit my safe file to get the ending that I believe I deserved completely destroyed the immersion and impact of the game.

For a game that presents itself as a choice-based narrative, and one that emphasizes the themes of being a decent human--not gaslighting or emotionally manipulating people--the game design itself is extremely manipulative by rendering choices meaningless. A player who behaved like a good, moral human being should be awarded for their good behaviour. But no, the morally decent player gets gaslit by the love interest--and by extension, the game designers.

I really want to recommend this game. I really do, especially because it's such a polished nostalgic gem. But Steam only has a "yes/no" option, so it'll have to be a "no" because the forced ending problem is entirely contrary to the game's core message and design philosophy. That said, I probably will still recommend it to people who would enjoy a throwback trip to 2008 with a VN-style dating sim, but I'd also preface my recommendation with the huge caveat as noted above, even at the expense of somewhat spoiling the ends.

[h1]Massive spoiler warning for Emily is Away, Emily is Away Too, and Emily is Away <3![/h1]

[h1] This review is really being written for people who have played all of the games in this series so far.[/h1]

With that being said:

[spoiler]I hate how the game basically gaslights the player into thinking they were either too controlling and manipulative, or too lax on the relationship during the first playthrough. This is despite the fact that no matter what you do in your first playthrough, your relationship with either Emily or Evelyn is over. You can also make the exact same choices you made in a new game, and have a better ending happen. This fact alone makes every other ending feel cheap and bitter, knowing you SHOULD have got them instead. Choice was removed on the first playthrough for a cheap and emotional "gut punch" ending that won't happen in any other playthough.[/spoiler]

I think literally no game in existence should ever do that to the player, and it felt like a huge "frick you" to someone who was actually sort of invested in the story and cared about some of the characters. With that said, I don't get why they did this whole [spoiler]"always a bad ending on first playthough"[/spoiler] thing. The first game, Emily is Away, [spoiler]does this sort of thing too. Thing is, at least the ending felt natural, sudden, and was pulled off in a heartbreaking and relatable way.[/spoiler] This game felt like they tried too hard to match the first game in terms of feelings, but actively [spoiler]FORCED the bad endings of the second game on the player rather than having them naturally occur due to your bad choices having impact.[/spoiler] Kind of disappointed in this game, because the other two felt so real and stressful. This one just pissed me off with how strange the writing direction was.

122473264.review:
[h1]Emily is Away <3[/h1] 
is a game where you sit on Facenook and chat to your friends about 2008 teenager life. From Senior year to Prom and the summer after, it's a bit of a ride but one well worth the time and it's advised you take your time. 

[b]The shorts[/b]
Play it if:
[list]
[*] You like story games
[*] You want to go back to those awkward 2008's when AIM just died and Facebook started out
[*] You can put this game open next to something else and reply as if it was actual Facebook. 
[/list]

Probably not play if:
[list]
[*] You expect an action-y game
[*] You want to skip dialogue, this takes a bit of time.
[*] You expect to go beyond Facenooks layout
[*] You need 3 medkits to heal from emotional damage. 
[/list]

[b]A few stats [/b]
Completion time for 1 story: 5 hours
Amount of endings: More then 1 
Replay-ability: Quite a bit if you want every possible ending. There are plenty of paths to walk

Most remarkable: Writing is actually very gripping and the provided answers are not different as they are presented. (I.e. LA Noire would have answers that sounded reasonable, but the character went off the handle. Doesn't happen here).

[b]Suggestion for first play through: [/b]
I got lured into the immersion as I had a series playing on my other screen. So you'll be replying to Facenook messages when they pop up and you're ' waiting' less for something to happen. It suckered me into the story and I certainly did feel for the ' people ' you're talking with. 

[b]Overall:[/b]
I enjoyed it as a game between games, if you enjoy story games that let you experience feelings and have you immersed into it this might be for you. I would suggest not to look up to much about the story and the game before playing, experiencing it the first time around is a bit of a ride. The game offers some fun surprises when clicking on presented links and it is definitely 2008. 

[b]Obligatory rating[/b]
I'd give it a 8 out of 10.

Emily is Away <3 is for sure, "first time, a charm". If you're not that keen on getting the good endings, you can aswell call it a day and drop the game after completing it for the first time. I managed to complete the whole game, with every ending but, every other replay just got really more and more repetetive, dull. I was both amazed and obliterated by how my first playthrough turned out, cause it reminded me of some feelings related to my past relationship and it definitely got me thinking about mine and my ex'es actions. But other than that, both Evelyn and Emily routes, are almost the same. I still find Evelyn actually more relatable than Emily, cause for me, she has the spirit and likes the same music I enjoy, lmao. But most of the choices were basically the same in both situations. I thought I'll be able to see story behind their friendship break up from two sides, but... It wasn't explained well enough. There's for sure some wasted potential there, but I bet the future version of the game, will be an amazing thing to play. And now, I'll tell u my two, completly viable and not questionable opinions. First of all, Mat is a fking banger friend and he's truly the treasure of this game, wish I could become gay towards him at this point. And second. Evelyn>Emily. The fact Evelyn made a playlist with Rise Against made her automatically my bestie, no cap. I guess that's it. If you love to involve yourself into relationship, then suddenly break up without knowing any reason why it had happened, blaming yourself or your partner, here's your chance. Cause your first playthrough is already designed to be a miserable one. That's how the game works, don't mind me.

Con:

121785301.review:
Like the previous two episodes, Emily 3: Dream Warriors is an interesting nostalgic look at high school life through the lens of the early days of social media. The main difference is rather than using AOL Instant Messenger as a framing device, this one goes into the Facebook era. Much like Emily 2, this game uses a fake YouTube page to simulate the teens sharing music with each other (and honestly sometimes it seems like "I like this genre of music" is their main personality trait, which can be a con of sorts), along with the new addition of being able to see other people's wall posts, and doing the old cheeky survey deal that everybody and their mother used to do.

The addition of allowing the game to type for you, letting you focus on reading the story and selecting the appropriate answer was a great new feature. I get that the idea was for you to "manually" type the IMs to feel more involved but it rarely felt how they were hoping for it, and honestly it got tedious after several in game days of it. So being able to just focus on the characters and world was pretty welcome. Everything is designed with being authentic in mind. The teens are sappy with wall posts that are song lyrics in lue of actual communication. They spell words horrifically for somebody who should have a high school education. Presentation wise it looks like you're in the era.

And as a story? It's an enjoyable journey. It's essentially a high school drama simulator, and it does it well. The fact you're also messaging side characters, such as your best friend in addition to the potential main relationship (one or two girls) also helps make it all feel more real. The bad part is after three separate games, it does get a bit old when we go back to the well of "well we have to BS a reason for the seemingly happy relationship to go to hell" for the third time. But, to be fair a lot of relationships go to die in the transition from high school to college so I can't give them too much crap for the repetitive nature of the series storytelling.

If you like little "slice of life" kinda games, this is worth a run through. That being said, if there's an Emily 4 I'm not sure I'd necessarily rush into buying it, expecting roughly the same overall story and ending for a fourth time in a row. Still, I don't regret the two dollarydoos I spent on this.

121635889.review:
Yikes! **** Jeff and Steve!

I love this game's sense of nostalgia, taking you back to the late 2000's era of early social media. It does an excellent job of building up these parasocial relationships--completely virtual--and making you feel attached to the no-faced characters of this game. I do also like the way the characters are represented! Each distinct person is given a different-colored silhouette, making them identifiable, but not setting their features in stone. You can project whoever you want onto them!

My main problem with "Emily is Away <3" comes in the story's messaging during the final chapters of the game; specifically Chapter 4 and 5 (the game only has five chapters). Spoilers ahead, so read with caution if you have yet to actually play the game:
[spoiler]I have quite an issue with the way the whole ending chapters of 4 and 5 are framed. The messaging it gives off--especially to younger high-school or middle-school aged children who could be new to relationships--is very alarming. For context: your girlfriend of choice in the game (either Emily or Evelyn) at some point becomes acquainted with a guy named Jeff/Steve (respectively). Jeff/Steve are going through some mental health issues, and your girlfriend gets closer with them through helping them. If you give your girlfriend the benefit of the doubt, she will eventually get so close to him that he convinces her to break up with you, and it is heavily suggested that she cheats on you with him. The lesson of the story here? Completely doubt your girlfriend, snoop on her friend's private profiles, intimidate him, and then question your girlfriend about it over and over. Every time she says that the conversation is making her uncomfortable, or she wants to stop, you simply have to keep on pushing and insist on having this conversation. Yes, seriously, that is what the game wants you to do. If you do this, suspect her, and convince her to drop her friends, you two stay together. If not, she breaks up with you. While, yes, this could very well be a real-life scenario, the messaging it gives of doubting your significant other, and having to question their loyalty and practically force them to follow your rules, is a bit odd.[/spoiler]

But that's just a complaint with the story. Besides that, I heavily enjoyed this game. I really love the touch of the characters sending you to an old 2000's version of YouTube, with real-life references, music, and memes from the era. Really takes you back! If you have a hard time socializing in real life, or want to have the typical "HS experiences" that you missed out on or are too afraid to have in-person, I highly recommend this game! It was very fun to build these relationships

121571744.review:
As much as I'd like to recommend this game, because the writing is actually pretty damn good, it sets a message that I'm not sure really..is a good message to be put out there--especially for anyone younger who is to play this game.

[spoiler]Basically, if you trust your partner, regardless of which girl you pick, and you don't try to pry into her life with the new friends she maked while in a relationship with you, you're giving her too much "Leeway to decide where your relationship is going" And she ultimately 'asks for a break' with a heavy hinting that she cheats on you. You're only capable of getting the 'good' ending if you question and doubt your partner just because she's talking with a guy who, when given the 'signs' is literally just asking her super simple normal friend things.[/spoiler]

The message is upsetting to me and maybe if it was only one of the two girls that this was the case for, it would be a personality thing and sort of make sense, but it sets the precedent that this is the normal way to approach a relationship which is in my opinion harmful.

Yes, I know, it's just a game. Yes, I know I sound like some kind of offended twitter little baby. These things usually don't bother me whatsoever, but with how much the dev is actually good at writing the whole rest of the dialogue between you and the characters, it's all too real. Maybe I'm wrong and I'm being silly, but I just had to write this.

120849655.review:
Once again a game where a neutral option is needed.

The game has some genuinely nice moments and the dialogue is mostly pretty good and had me smile at times. Problem is:

1. Sometimes you have three options, but they are so remarkably close to one another when all I wanted was to end the conversation or at least the subject. Leads to some unnecessarily "awkward" moments.

2. (SPOILER AHEAD) The game forces you to play through it a second time which leads to a positive ending as getting a happy end on your first playthrough is seemingly impossible without changing the game code - regardless of your choices. This means even being the perfect boyfriend means you get robbed of a pleasurable conclusion.

Now a second attempt wouldn't be all that bad if not for the fact that even though I chose the different girl, the dialogue is almost exactly the same with alterations to names, favourite music genres and the field they are going to study (however with the relationship between the two from the other perspective obviously), making the second time more of a chore than fun since I was aiming for that good ending. I was hoping for her to be a different character, but the two girls are basically clones with different names.

3. I tried out some things like congratulating the other girl for her birthday and poking some people that hadn't initiated the conversation with me - to no avail. I may have missed something (as plenty of achievements have not yet been reached, but those additional buttons seem to be just for show most of the time and I have lost interest in replaying it again.

120768153.review:
The idea for the story seems very generic but the execution really elevates this experience. Everything is told through Facenook, a social media website similar to its real-life counterpart. 
	
By creating this atmosphere for the game, it did a really good job of taking me through the way-back machine. Heck, I think I had even started my Facebook profile in 2008 around the time I left high school. There is a lot here that was a blast from the past from the back and forth with the different IMs, the pokes, the music, etc.

I felt the writing did a good job to convey this high schooler mentality and the exchanges with the other characters felt realistic. I can't say I was a fan of how to get the different endings mainly because a lot of it will be replaying similar scenes. And you're locked out of getting the ending that you want unless you take the other path. For myself, I just went and edited the save file because I wasn't interested in playing it any longer than that.

That aside, it's a good game to play through at least once. Currently it's in the August 2022 Humble Choice so if you're interested in this or any of the other games you can check out my review here: https://youtu.be/9ZJ85aW5thE

120599768.review:
This game made me go from having a wonderful time, relieving the highs and lows that was 2000's internet and school drama, to leaving a terrible taste in my mouth. And no, it's not because it was sad, I came here to feel after all. The non-spoiler reason? I'll just say it's the incentive for doing a second and third playthrough. The secret, hidden, literally never explained reason people had to dig into the code to find? 

[spoiler] You cannot win the first time through. You will always, no matter what, get the bad end. on a new game+, you are able to get the good ending with the girl you DIDNT pick last time. and then round 3 you can try to get the route you want. I feel so cheated, the 4 hours going through this were apparently a waste. Like one of those boss fights where you win, then lose in the cutscene afterward, except it's the entire game. And worse, the routes are basically the same, tons of repeating dialogue. So they made a game you had to replay to win, then made it slow to replay. Yes, visial novels do this, but they add a speed up button! This game doesn't even have you hit next by default, you have to keysmash out each letter unless you change the settings![/spoiler] 

That frankly soured everything for me. This was going to be a strong recommend, a game I was actively thinking of doing multiple runthroughs of while playing, which is rare. but I really cannot recommend it after that. There have been many games I've rated, but this is one of the saddest ones. Not for the ending, but for what could've been.

I still have to finish the second playthrough, but man this brings back memories.
Admittedly, I never played the other two and I'm pretty sure that I mostly watched youtubers playing them, so when I found out that this was included within a bundle over Humble or Fanatical, I had to buy it.

The premise itself is alone the main and interesting part of it all. Being able to see how was back then, with the pokes, with the statuses that everyone could watch, those s****t challenges and questions. Those were the times, the golden times in which most of us that went to school didn't had to care at all in the slighest about life, about being adult. Just wanna have fun, write dumb stuff every now and then, poke everyone. And man, I remember how I was scared, sometimes, of poking the one I liked because she of course could've saw that! 

But talking about the game, even if these are just fictional characters, you can't just go on without feeling something for each of them (and man, Mat? Is the best. Luckily I have one friend just like him, my best friend, and I just hope we'll stick to each other 'till the very end) because at the end of the day? What happened inside, happened to all of us at least one time in our life. And we most likely acted just like they did, pretty sure.

In conclusion, I would definitely recommend this.

120152335.review:
If you were around the time when things like Xfire and TeamSpeak were the leading IMs around, you'll get hit with a lot of nostalgia with this game. It's essentially a social game where you've left your old instant messenger for Facebook, and you're being social with all your friends on there.

Given I haven't finished this game, so far from what I've played, I've genuinely enjoyed. I saw a review on here that claimed the game is boring, and I think it has to do with more of that nostalgia factor. Maybe if you weren't growing up with those old IMs, this game won't hit you like it does to the people, like myself, who were growing up during that time. Honestly, the game is very simple though, you'll get messages and posts on Facebook and you have three options to reply with. I can see how this would be boring to a lot of people, but this game is intended to immerse you in that old genre of IMs and social media, compared to the horrendous versions we have in the modern day. This is a good way to "relive the past", even if it's with AI who pretend to be real people.

I couldn't finish it, got to the end of chapter 3 and was really bored just wishing it would end, so had to drop it. I preferred the last two games. This third entry was just boring. This is down to the fact that the formula has gotten quite stale now. 

The nostalgia and sad atmosphere from the previous games doesn't hit anymore either, as it has already been done and that this game is set on facebook, something i'm not really all that nostalgic for. Atmosphere was a big part of the last two games but with this one it wasn't there.

Ultimately I think it's time to either end the Emily is Away series, and for the dev to move onto something else because there is game dev talent here. Or for the series to tell a completely different story that isn't about teen romance. I know the dev tried to shake this up, as it's a lot 'bigger' than the last two games, both from content perspective (it's longer than the last two games, with a bit more to interact with) and characters, but we really need a complete shake up if this series is to continue.

119240137.review:
TL;DR: Great game, excellent story & world-building, I absolutely recommend!

"Emily is Away <3" does a great job at really immersing you in its world, investing you in its characters, and pulling at your emotions—much more so than I expected it would when I bought the game. 
All the little funny websites, secrets, and just general attention to detail really elevate the whole experience: I especially enjoyed the use of the "YouToob" music playlists! Even the whole typing random keys on your keyboard in order to "write" out your messages thing, which at first seemed pretty gimmicky and silly, totally grew on me: "typing" out the messages definitely made the whole story feel more real to me and just kinda made the experience more fun.
Also, having just finished my senior year in real life, to walk back through that time in a different, imaginary world, was quite nostalgic, & enjoyable to do so without having to worry about any of the schoolwork.

Definitely a game worth buying, especially considering it's just $10—plus the game is definitely re-playable; I've just finished my first play-through of the game, and I definitely plan to play it through at least once more.

118246964.review:
This game initially left me feeling like nothing I ever do in my future relationships could save me from the eventual feeling that people seemingly just...inadvertently grow into different people after the 'honeymoon phase' of being together. 

You can be the most supportive, understanding partner on the planet, but what does it mean? Why does that matter if the person you pour attention, love, respect and admiration into starts to feel that the two of you have grown apart, even if you don't feel that way yourself? I'm serious, this series makes me feel this way because, while there are 'happy' endings where you end up with Emily, it's practically impossible without limiting your significant other and forcing her to convert to your skewed way of thinking, and is that really fair to the other person in the first place? What does getting the happy ending even mean if I've meddled and coerced the person I supposedly love into thinking she feels more strongly than she really does? At what point is it fair to myself to trudge through the sad reality that the person I'm in love with just wants something simpler than what we are, and why punish myself mentally and emotionally for that if it means we'll both just be unhappy, EVEN IF there's ever a chance that we could work things out and grow, if in the end it's all forced and not real?

[b]And that's where this game comes with a lesson for me.[/b]

It's easy to say that Emily/Evelyn is a terrible partner because, in the more common of these endings, it ends up not being anything you or they did, but moreso the sad reality that, sometimes, people change. They move on, their feelings change as time goes on and sometimes, sadly, people just [i]grow apart.[/i]

Emily is Away <3 is, in my opinion, a great way to teach people that sometimes things just can't work out regardless if you love each other and that sometimes in life, it's better for everyone to cut off the wound and let time heal all, and I think the happier of the endings is a way for people to feel like they've fulfilled certain things and truly beaten the game, though who cares what I say, it's ultimately up to how people interpret these things themselves and I can't tell you what this game should mean to you, that's up to you to play it for yourself and take your own thoughts away.

Do I think you should play the Emily is Away series, let alone this one? [b]Yes.[/b] 

I think this game sort of helped me understand that in life, things aren't always just perfect moments without consequence where things can work out because the love you have for your partner is strong, because sadly it may not be that way for both parties and it's harder than just talking it out and coming to a root cause. 

It really is a great game in that regard. all the 2008 musings and stylings of the early internet aside, (and I really do give credit to that aspect of the game, it's really a nostalgic and beautiful call back to those days of Hotmail, AOL, and Facebook in the late 2000's) I think this game teaches really interesting messages to those that have the capacity and want to hear them.

Goodbye, Emily.

118228512.review:
As the final game of the Emily is Away series, this game really leans in hard on the olden days of Facebook. The AIM simulation is gone as this game takes place in a time when it was out-competed by other instant messengers. Although all 3 Emily is Away games are unrelated in terms of story, the development of Emily is Away <3 does build on what was done in previous games. Therefore, you can choose to play any game in any order and it won't impact the story of any one in any way.

More endings and paths can be achieved with this game and trying to figure out how to reach all the paths is a real mental gymnastics. I was able to get one of the rarer endings on a replay just by changing a few of my decisions. If you already enjoy playing the previous 2 games in this series, Emily is Away <3 will also be enjoyable for you.

117854817.review:
TL/DR.:

Overall I really recommend this game... but only for one playthrough. The first one will be awesome if you want to "relive" the past, the second playthrough will just take away even the first ones good feelings. It became repetitive and while I felt like I'm speaking to a real person on the first run, the second ruined this feeling.

---

I absolutely adore this game, even with its mistakes.

What I love the most about it, is that it managed to bring back feelings from the past, I never thought I would feel again he tension of choosing the good words to woo the girl, the teen dramas that -I think- everybody experienced in some way or another and even the cringe how I used to talk as a teenager. 

Overall for a first playthrough, it's really an emotional amusement park. Not so much for the second though, but I'll get back to this later.

The biggest complaint I have is that I learned, you can't have the happiest ending for the first playthrough. While I understand the notion behind this (even if you do everything correctly, a relationship might just end), I still felt cheated. I replayed the last chapters 2 times to see if I can change the outcome, but it just didn't happen. After getting more and more frustrated, I decided to look up if there is even a "best ending" and that's when I learned, I would have to start again a new "campaign". That means if I want the best ending with my first chosen girl (Team Evelyn here), I would have to do EVERYTHING from the beginning. 

I tried starting a new campaign with choosing Emily now, so I don't have to do the same conversations, but unfortunately they were 95% the same (except for a few sentences). So I just gave up, and looked for a way to change my original playthrough save file so it registers as a second playthrough and that gave me the satisfying best ending. 

Overall I really recommend this game... but only for one playthrough. The first one will be awesome if you want to "relive" the past, the second playthrough will just take away even the first ones good feelings. It became repetitive and while I felt like I'm speaking to a real person on the first run, the second ruined this feeling.
