115964114.review:
This is a conflicting review to make due to my own personal bias toward the game series, but also the glaring flaws the game has. TL;DR, would I recommend the game? If you liked the first two Emily is Away games, I'd say a rather confident "yes." However, if the story is the one thing keeping you on the fence, I can give you a rather genuine review of the story despite my own bias.

Emily is Away had a wonderful story to tell of a young adult protagonist trying to confess his love to his crush. In that game, you could truly feel the tension of the protagonist, the fear of rejection, and the excitement when things went okay! It is a basic love story about a friendship you want to blossom into love, and then watching as you inevitably drift apart due to college. It really hit home for a lot of people, especially those who actually lived through the AOL Instant Messenger days.

Emily is Away Too had a very similar story, but you got to grow close to either one of the characters - Emily or Evelyn - and not only was it another masterpiece of nostalgia, but also your standard dating sim with multiple choices that actually mattered.

Emily is Away <3, as you may have guessed, has the exact same story. But it did not execute it as well as Emily is Away Too did. The main reason being Emily and Evelyn have no personalities of their own anymore. In Emily is Away Too, you could distinctly tell these two girls were polar opposites of each other. They had their own tastes in music, their own dreams, their own paths in life, their own ways of speaking. However, in this game, they are mere clones of one another. The only difference in dialogue you'll see when romancing one or the other is a change in name here and there. For example, my first playthrough was an Emily route. She says to the protagonist "Hey, no byes. Never byes." At the time, I thought it was a super cute thing Emily had for her own character. I was rather disappointed when I quickly learned in my second playthrough on an Evelyn route that she said the exact same thing. That was when I realized these two characters have the same exact dialogue.

In Emily is Away Too, the characters were so different that even their ways of talking were specific to them. Little things like Evelyn being a bit more vulgar than Emily or Emily being a little more shy than Evelyn were what made these characters so different. That is what is severely lacking in this game. A sense of character.

So, is this game worth it?
For the experience of a classic Emily is Away game? I think so. The fact that it is set on Facebook caters to my childhood, so that really helped convince me to buy the game. The immersive story may be a bit lost with the game's obvious flaws, but the overall experience I'd rate a 7.5/10. However, I don't necessarily think I'd recommend this game to those who find the stories of games like this the most important part. So, buy at your own risk is my final consensus. 

I loved the game, I thought it was rather enjoyable and a good time waster if nothing else. If you do buy it, I hope you enjoy it, too!

115602659.review:
I had to put down this one a bit early. When I saw the direction the story was moving in, it triggered some major social anxiety and I haven't had the resolve to return to it since. Even though I’m quite keen on this method of storytelling and found a lot to like about Emily is Away 3’s presentation and narrative gameplay, I'm not particularly fond of doing polite social damage control for a cast of rather archetypal teenagers.

Simply because the game told me that they were my friends, I was inorganically compelled to agree with these strangers, choose the kindest options, and play the middleman out of fear of any negative story consequences. It felt like going to a friend’s party, being told all about that friend’s friends on the drive there, and then talking to those mutuals yourself. You have to play it nice, nod your head a lot, and avoid taking sides because even though you know these people, you don’t really “know” them, ya know?

Personal tangents aside, Emily is Away 3 is logically the next chronological step in the series of retro-internet text-based romance narratives. The jump forward to 2008 means Facenook™ is now the social platform of choice for this instance of Emily and Evelyn. Multi-tasking between posts and conversations on desktop social media is done with a slightly unnerving amount of authenticity. As with the other Emily is Away games, it’s odd yet obvious to write a story about the concerns and relationships of young adults through the medium they would actually use for casual communication. In many ways, this is a prime example of the advantages that interactive media has over other traditional mediums. The sensation of being on the internet during that decade is captured more succinctly here than it is by simply browsing the Wayback Machine or watching ancient YouTube videos. I would’ve never guessed that the original free Emily is Away would lead to a trilogy and it’s been very interesting to see how the messaging software affects the stories they tell.

115029347.review:
Emily is Away <3 is an excellent time machine, and third in the series by creator Kyle Seeley. The music mentioned in the game sets the tone for the year that the game is based in, and it transports me to a time where I experienced very similar narrative happenings. During my teen years, a memorable vibe of my life was going back home after school and talking to my friends on social media apps like Facebook, Kik and Google+. 

It's surreal to experience something like that in a game a decade later, with people that don't even exist! Simple things like texting 2 people at the same time really quickly in (not so)tense situations with potential interpersonal consequences are what make this game so immersive.

I'd never have thought that such a mundane aspect of life would be so significant to me all these years later, and I have this series to thank for it!

114949371.review: Emily is away is a nostalgia/dating sim in which you take the role of a high school senior working through their last year of school. The layout of the game was a knock off of Facebook called Facenook. I will say it was incredibly accurate to how things were in 2008, messaging friends and angsty statuses were well captured. The background computer sounds were also a nice touch as they really sold the idea of using a late 2000s computer. The storyline was very "highschoolish". You make the choice of pursuing either Evelyn or Emily and date them throughout the school year. The dialog and the things that you interact with on Facenook really made a difference to the story. For example, Evelyn made a facenook post on my profile and I chose to ignore it, she got the memo and didn’t message my character again. Dynamic interactions like that made the game fun and engaging.Overall I would rate the game 8.5/10, the only downside that I could think of is the replay value, in a second playthrough I chose to pursue Evelyn instead of Emily and found that almost the exact dialog was used for both girls.

Okay, so this is a dating sim disguised as a nostalgia simulator, which is completely fine. Teenage love stories are not my thing but the effort of bringing back the old Facebook made me stay. The characters, the plot, and the general setting are nice; even though they are a little cringeworthy, the characters are supposed to be teenagers so I cannot complain. "youtoob.com" and the music lists are absolutely hilarious and well done. And my first playthrough was nice enough with a bad ending. I thought " Okay, that was sad but a good story overall. I wonder if I could have changed that outcome." And boy here we are:

I learned that you need to play the same story AGAIN, but choose the other person as your romantic interest. Wtf? The "good" ending is hidden in a newgame+ mode despite the fact that you picked the acceptable answers for a "good ending run" in your first go? Okay fine, a little jarring, but fine. I was going to leave it at that but the supposed good ending bugged me so I restarted, chose the other character and my positive initial viewpoint of the game completely vanished in front of my eyes as I went through the EXACT SAME SCENARIO. I picked the other character, how come she is completely the same person as the green one but purple. Same feelings on disputed story arcs, same dialogue lines on most things, same anti-bye nonsense (I don't get it either, I'm too old.), same pictures (purple instead of green, yay!), almost the same "rival" love interest (The only difference is his name). There are no distinct personality features. The two are the same person with a different colour scheme. And the green girl married the yellow girl the moment she noticed I realised this. You can't fool me game! The green and the purple girl are the same person. Anyway, I couldn't handle all the teenage drama with this new knowledge, so I'm not recommending it.

114541802.review:
[B]Mathew Gursky sos un ser de luz, gracias por ser el mejor amigo que pude haber tenido.[/b]

Ahora fuera de bromas, después de haberme jugado "Emily is Away", "Emily is Away Too" y "Emily is Away <3" solo puedo decir cosas positivas de estos. Me parece EXCELENTE la idea de que la interfaz de los tres títulos este basada en un software viejo como lo es el Windows XP, que este el facebook antiguo también, el YouTube, todo es la nostalgia hecha un videojuego. Otra cosa que "Emily is Away" hace muy bien es contagiar o hacer sentir sentimientos específicos en el jugador, con esto me refiero a que si en dicha parte del juego hay un problema con tu pareja (sea Emily o Evelyn) vas a sentir el peso de la discusión, la incomodidad, el temor de que se eche todo a perder, etc. En este en especifico me parece SUPER POSITIVO y de gran valor el personaje de Mat que en el caso de mi playthrough simbolizó perfectamente a ese amigo que esta en todas, en las buenas y en las malas, que sabe cuando vos estas mal e intenta todo para mejorar tu día. Aunque en ninguno de los tres pude quedarme en pareja, en este me quedé re feliz porque por lo menos no me quedé solo, ahi estuvo Mat :'). EN FIN, super recomendados los TRES EMILY IS AWAY porque son ALTA experiencia por un precio bastante económico.

114481392.review:
I've been a huge fan of the Emily Is Away series ever since they released the first one back in the day, and I've loved everything they've done with the story and characters in those games. Emily is Away Too was a huge improvement on the formula of the first game, even adding a second choice girl, Evelyn.
And in this game, both of them are back, with the addition of other friends and foes you get to chat with on the new Facenook app.

But unfortunately, not everything is as peachy as could be. Long gone are the trepidations of the original game, where you'd choose one option, yet the main character would opt out of writing it, leaving you in a state of powerlessness, which is par for the course when doing something like confessing to the girl of your dreams. And long gone are the differing storylines for the 2 main girls, Evelyn and Emily, from Emily is Away Too, which added a breath of fresh air, and an actual happy ending to the story, which were all welcome changes. But unfortunately, the same cannot be said for this sequel.

This game has 2 main stories, with a few differing aspects here and there, but in fact, if you play past the first chapter on your second playthrough, you'll find that that is actually a lie, because Emily and Evelyn's dialogues are the exact same. There is no difference in their stories whatsoever: everything single thing they both go through, and everything they say in the chats is the exact same, with the only difference being a name swap here and there.

It's quite sad to see from this team of devs that showed such promise before in the creation of their stories, and even though the game's atmosphere and world building, with fake websites that ACTUALLY work are very impressive, the story department is just very lacking. And we all know why we came here: to be heartbroken by 2 different girls, but instead we get a clone story.

114330426.review:
This game really messed me up and I loved it.
I had my first real relationships back in like 2009-2011ish and playing this game just made me remember so much things from back then. It captures the era perfectly. The way the game begins lays the groundwork as you react to things on your timeline like a cog in the algorithm machine and then you are whisked away in time to the summer of 2008 where you have real interaction with real people that you know - in the game at least. And seeing all that made me really nostalgic and really sad at the same time when I started to recall how fun things like Facebook, YouTube and MySpace were back in the day.
And the way this game portrays the relationship highs and lows during that late 2000's and early 2010's is just so realistic. The characters are fleshed out beautifully and they have distinct personalities and styles of writing and your own dialogue options never seem out of place or make you loose your touch with your own character in the game. I just loved every minute of this game and it also made me remember that I was kind of an idiot and a jerk when I was a teenager and because of the portrayal of the peaks and valleys of the Facebook -era dating, it kinda messed with me and really got under my skin - but in a good way.

I really recommend it if you were a high school kid in the turn of the 2010's. It really captures the zeitgeist of that time perfectly.

So, overall it's a good game, although I like it less than second part for few reasons. One of which is a gameplay spoiler that I'll describe later, the other one is basically less of an emotional rollercoaster. Everything is usually going smooth and pretty predictable with almost no problems to overcome. I guess it's good on one hand, but less interesting on the other. Although if it was the only problem, I would probably enjoy it more than 2 previous games since I like this gameplay more. It's not only texting, but also interacting with people other ways even though it's really nothing much it feels more real (expecially since I've never used text messengers a lot, but somewhat more familiar with social networks).  Now about real problem and why I think it's stupid. [spoiler] As far as I know it's impossible to get good ending no matter what you do in your first playthrough. So you always get dumped, which in story really doesn't make much sense and can be described as "teenagers sometimes can be stupid". And in particular the ending I got was the best you can get in first playthrough and it feels uncompleted. You're taking a break with your gf and nobody knows what happens next, so you can only assume, that you broke up and it's the end. But wait, it gets worse, not only good ending doesn't have any new choices in second and further playthroughs and just ends differently for no reason, good ending only gets unlocked on the side of the DIFFERENT girl. Which mean you have to get bad ending with other girl to unlock good with the one you picked which makes zero sense. Not only most people wouldn't want to replay after getting bad ending, the ones who would want would probably replay with the same girl and get bad ending again. [/spoiler]
Same spoiler, but TL;DR
[spoiler] First playthrough you get dumped no matter what. It unlocks good ending with opposite girl. So if you want good ending with Emily you have to get bad with Evelyn first and vise versa. Good ending is completely the same except for the 5th chapter which is basically a result for all you did. So in good ending you can make the same choices but get a different result from the bad one [/spoiler]
It makes me feel very weird, especially since I think it all could be avoided pretty easily. I guess it is part of series feature by now, but imo it's even worse that was done in the first game. And it also looked really weird kinda like in this game in the first playthrough.[/spoiler] On the bright side, again as far as I know, unlike second game this one isn't as strict with your choices, so you can make minor mistakes here and there and it won't affect your ending.

I'm only about three-quarters through this game, but I think based on the previous games, it's enough to make a review.

This is a far better game than the first two and it shows. The nostalgia, the typing noises, the emoticons and words, the music choice. Kyle has done an amazing job here. I play this with my sister, and the two of us really do feel transported back to the late-00s Facebook era. 

The characters are so well-written (literally lol), and the dynamic that you get when in text-based conversation really comes through. Does Emily mean what she said sincerely? Oh, she was joking. Thank god. 

Or does she? Who knows? That's the beauty of text. 

In short: Kyle Seeley has distilled the early Facebook aesthetic while developing a beautiful, rich, and emotionally turbulent game that tugs at my heart better than any videogame has.

I really cannot wait for EIA 4, but I don't know what comes after 'Facenook' lol. WhatsApp? Messenger?

I really enjoyed the use of "Youtoob" very nice way of getting music into your game and also adding in a bit of immersion. I loved the use of wall posts and the different profiles each character has, but I would be nice to have the ability to change your profile and have the characters react to it.

Overall, I did enjoy this game, but if Kyle Seeley plans to make a fourth installment, I hope that there will be more variety in dialogue and the characters. This game has it's flaws, but I'm glad I played it nonetheless.

A remarkably potent shot of nostalgia for the early Facebook generation.

Digg! A Softer World! Post Secrets! The unholy, endless conflict of poke wars! Compatibility quizzes and endless song lyrics! I haven't thought about these things in over a decade! 

The internet moves so quickly, and the interactive spaces we grew up using as social tools are now gone for good or vastly changed. It was fun to go back and visit, but I don't think this will appeal much to anybody who wasn't graduating high school around 2008. For those of us that did, this is a frozen moment in time. Highly recommended.

Even disregarding the nostalgia, this game is amazing at having you create bonds with other people. At some points, I legitimately regretted actions from an emotional instead of logical standpoint, Sometimes, I felt like an asshole. Sometimes, I was thankful for my friends, and at other points, I was worried I'd lose them.

Even after the game, I felt shitty for a few days. I don't know if it was the withdrawal from talking to everyone, the ending I got, or something entirely different, but I do know it was because of Emily is Away <3. Don't take that as a warning to not play, but as a reassurement this game absolutely creates connections between you and the characters and the situations they're in. 

As another little tidbit, I've played Spec Ops: The Line before because of all the review praising it's emotional story. With no spoilers, at the end of the game, I felt none of this. Maybe it was an average or slightly above average in terms of story, but it was not as good as what people were saying, at least for me. I'm led to believe it was because it wasn't immersive enough or something for me, but this game does immersion right.

TL;DR, This game is amazing at immersion and getting you to care about the characters, your choices, and the effects of those choices

110109001.review:
[h1] Amazing game but it could have been much better [/h1]
Emily is Away 3 is a fantastic experience and I highly recommend purchasing the game for yourself and playing through it. However, with that out of the way, I do believe that EIA3 could have been much better than what we were given.

[b] Complaints [/b]
One of the major complaints I have about EIA3 is how your character's actions (in this case, what you choose to say) does not really matter. There are only a select few decisions that you have to make that really impact the way the story plays out or how the characters view you. This wasn't a major issue during my first play through as you don't realize until your second run that most of your actions do not really affect things. This really made the second run of the game feel lackluster, as i knew that most of my actions didn't matter anyways.

Now another complaint was that not only were you forced to only interact with Emily OR Evelyn during the course of most of the game, but both their routes were virtually the same, with a few minor changes. This REALLY killed the second run for me. I frankly barely cared about it, and I only really went through a second run because 1. [spoiler] you can only get a good ending during your second run [/spoiler] 2. I wanted to achievement hunt. 

[b] Bottom-line [/b]
This game really was fantastic and I really do hope that Emily is Away 4 is released in the near future, as I would definitely buy and play it. EIA3 was amazing despite some of its flaws, now its time to use those mistakes to make an even better experience than the last. Keep up the fantastic work Kyle!

108123261.review:
QUICK NOTE

Okay, just a quick little statement here, im not a serious person as you can tell from my profile and i barley leave reviews and its mostly some random shit, but i firmly believe that this game needs a review from me. Ill try not to spoil a buncha stuff too so beware!


Okay to get into this shit,

MY PLAY THROUGH DETAILS

I came into the game not really knowing anything but it was a "dating sim", I logged into the game and came up with the choice of choosing your profile character, and i chose one (no duh). I Started my adventure and came across your best friend in the game, Mat, who showed me, The player, how to work the game and what its all about, I was also introduced to Mat's personal life and got a little more insight on his character, hes a rambunctious and a full of angst teenager (like most teens in 2009) (my cousin was one of them lmfao). Anyways we come to the first interactions with someone other than mat, Emily and Evelyn, and got to know a little bit about them and their characters. Then came the time to chose either going to Emily's BBQ or Evelyn's party; I replied maybe to both events (I had no idea i couldn't change it). After getting a glance throughout both of their pages I decided to go to Evelyn's party because why not it was a god damn party! That basically summed up chapter 1 for me.

INITIAL THOUGHTS OF CHAPTER 1
1. I thought it was a good introduction to the game
2. The Characters and world building were good for being short
3. Gave me a difficult time thinking on whose party i should attend
4. Everything was lively there was not a bare moment

As I Continued on to chapter 2, It was the spookiest time of year October and im not going to lie i kinda cringed (not kinda A Lot) reading some of the dialogue. I also learned of Mats Halloween party and thought hell yeah Mat's cool why not! This is where the dating sim actually started in the story, Mat texts you and pulls up a photo from the party that i chose to go to and it was Evelyn's arm around and being Mat he thought there was something there (Little did he know) and that's the point where i actually started to use how i would actually feel in that situation so i play around the point that Evelyn is pretty hot. Then I learned that My character and Evelyn were already planning on "hanging out" at the movies. A conversation ensues eventually we admit that its a date and guess what! My character and Evelyn got into a relationship! I felt a sense of accomplishment which i barley feel from games like these (throughout the review this will be a common theme).  that's the bare bones of chapter two!

INITIAL THOUGHTS OF CHAPTER 2
1. I enjoyed how the choices of the last major selection actually impacted the story in major ways
2. Enjoyed the conversation between my character and Mat, Evelyn as well
3. This is the party of the story where i became emotionally invested and wanted to see more
4. Gave a lot more insight on Evelyn and what she likes and what she doesn't like
5. The satisfaction of the end of the chapter brought me visible happiness

Ah chapter 3, Though a good chapter there was really nothing much except for Mats problem and the statement of the ages by Evelyn (Im going to talk about this more), Though i felt accomplished earlier it carried on little until this point, the sheer emotion and excitement that filled up my body. I was honestly confused at first but i realized that the writing that went into this game was beautiful and it was reaching me on an emotionally level. At this point i felt like i was in that moment like im the character, like that was my reality. No game has done that so i give it major applause for doing so.

INITIAL THOUGHTS OF CHAPTER 3 (going to keep it short)
1. Amazing writing
2. Loved the chemistry between charactes
3. world building was really good

Chapter 4 and 5, i know i went like in full depth with the other chapters but this is something you want to experience for yourselves, so ill give you guys my initial thoughts in more detail to make up for it. These two chapters legitimately broke me. Im still confused at this moment, i felt genuine sadness, jealousy, and anger. I have multiple reasons why i relate with this so much some recent and some in the past but still, how Kyle Steeley wrote this out was terrific and honestly made me love this game already more than I liked it, And if you want to hear more about the stories i went through that relates to the plot or helped gave a deeper understanding of the game, i may make another post explaining it in more depth (yes, spoilers). 

FINAL THOUGHTS
This game though having some flaws in itself is worth every single penny, ive never felt so invested and excited to play a game like this in years. Thank you for the experience and i cant wait for more.

-CallMeConvict

107617429.review:
=== MAJOR SPOILER WARNING ===

Emily is Away <3 (~4hrs/run) is so far the latest installment in the series, and instead of AIM as the platform of communication, it moves to a parody of early Facebook; this opens many possibilities as multi-level interactions, walls and public communication and view is a factor to consider. I played Emily is Away <3 as close as I could to reality as well (apart from my poor communication skills), choosing the quieter, more reserved Emily over the party-going Evelyn. The division between the two is only really in the first part of the game, where the two were friends and you must choose who's party to go to with your friend Mat and his GF. Things go relatively well, and that if you have some degree of problem solving and interpersonal skills you can breeze right through close to the end being happy with everyone. You help Emily reconcile with Evelyn after a falling out, the way being that they both need to let go, that things won't ever be the same. Emily mentions a major thing, she hates byes.
At the early parts, it is suggested that your friend Mat is cheating on his GF as mentioned by the opposite party's girl. This is a subject you can play, but I don't think it was true. Later on he is dumped by his GF who says he was always faithful and that she just grew into a different person. You can choose to ditch your plans with your other person and be with him or ditch him in his sorrow. Of course I helped the poor lad, approved of by Emily after. As the game goes on, there is enough drama to keep your attention but nothing extreme. Either Jeff or Steve with appear posing a 'threat' to your relationship, and it turns out as your choice whether to get jealous and accusatory, in which is can go either way.  (edited)

 At the end for your first playthrough (if you decided to pursue a girl), they will loose feelings and either break up with you or put the relationship into a 'break'. Having supported your friend Mat (who you may have helped into a new relationship) he sees that your relationship has broken down and will invite you over, much like you helped him. Evelyn who has had a good year, will also invite you to a graduation party.
In the last few lines, Emily thanks you for always being there for her, and that you've been a great friend, her last words to you are "bye, (name)". Emily is Away <3 is about growing up and changing like the others. But it is more than that, Emily is Away <3 is about learning to let go yourself through helping others; that relationships and best friends come and go, but good friends will always be there to stay.  I give Emily is Away <3  10/10, it would be wrong to give it anything lower from how well it kept my attention and made me actually feel immersed and involved. (edited)

And that has been my journey. Like I said, there isn't a whole lot in this world that can make me truly feel, but these games certainly have. I think most people should have cried throughout these, or at least at the ending; maybe I should have too? I love all three of these games, and at some point I will play through them all again. They possess a perfect existence, connected yet separated; alternative realities. I give them all an overall rating of 10/10, I probably won't play anything like them for long time. Thank you.

106780103.review:
Before I get to the actual review, lemme say that this isn't a 'wow good game'-review, this is a 3/5 stars review and it annoys me more than ever that steam's rating system is so black and white. 


Now to the game! 
Because of the higher price I expected more content than in the previous game and they delivered on that part. I felt that the game was neither to short 'nor too long.
 
The two love interests from the second game are returning, so you'll see some familiar faces! At first I was like woah, nice! But all that excitement vanished into thin air once I went for my second playthrough. 
From chapter 2 until the end it really doesn't matter what girl you pick in the first chapter (yes you have to chose your girl early on in the game). I played emily's route and then I went for evelyn. It got boring quick. 
Sure, I don't expect some totally different story but like,, at most times you don't even notice a single difference. Even the "conflict" is  e x a c t l y  the same. 

So this game's got bad replayability. Now maybe you aren't really supposed to replay this game anyways, so it's understandable it's made that way... wait, you can't even get a good ending unless you have atleast two playthroughs?? Yeah when I found out I was surprised too. 
At first I thought this was like the very first emily is away, you're just doomed to get a sad ending and your heart broken in the process. But nope, you can get a good ending... if you're willing to replay this now suddenly feeling way too long game.


It's not all bad actually, I just needed to get my frustration outta the way first. 
There were things I really loved, one of them being your best friend mat (I'm not gonna lie, I wish you could've gone for him instead of the girls!). He's really fun and has his own story throughout the game.

Another thing I loved are the photos! If you can even call them that, it's actually just pixelated pics but that's part of the charm. 
The whole facenook design didn't feel quite as nostalgic as the AIM design but I still like it more. You can do way more stuff (almost like the real deal lol), like writing on people's walls and set a status.

Also that you can actually interact with people other than your two love interests is a huuuge upgrade! (Like i already mentioned, mat's the best)


So yea, don't get me wrong, I love the Emily is Away franchise, this is why it's even harder for me to write a not-so-good-not-so-bad review. 
This game made me wanna replay Emily is Away Too but for all the wrong reasons... guess it's gonna stay my favorite out of the three. 
In conclusion: do I recommend this game? To die-hard Emily fans like me, yes I do. It's nice to see your favorite characters again and especially getting those pixelated photos of your own character and the girl is really sweet. But for people who aren't invested in the characters, don't set your expectations to high. [strike]If you haven't played Emily Too, play that one instead.[/strike]

106132451.review:
Alright, this game has it's ups and it's downs, but is still very much worth it.
It made me feel feeeeeels, and that seems to be the point. 
It does have a very nostalgic feel to it, it even provides you with big playists to indulge in while browsing a very obvious parody of a famous social network. 
The characters feel amazingly real, I got fully sucked into the story and had moments to truly reflect on what I was about to say. Moreover, it made me think about my own life and the choices I made or made. Thia game might even be heartbreaking, and I hope it doesn't leave a scar on sensitive souls. Be careful.
And now, a LITTLE SPOILER that I need to complain about:
[spoiler]I got frustrated and bitter about the fact that no matter how well you handle the situation the first time, you get a bad ending. The game is designed that way, you have to play it twice to get a good one. And what's worse you have t play the second one romancing another girl. 
What if I don't want to romance Evelyn? I specifically liked Emily and wanted her to be my canon romance. I don't like the fact that you have to fiddle with the game save to have the satosfying ending you deserve or just accept the bitter one. I think this could have been handled better. [/spoiler]

Anyway, thank you for the experience! Gotta check the other parts!

105174136.review:
The second part of the series was the worst imo, so I didn't expect much from the third part. But I was pleased to find out I was wrong. This game is better: great visual, nice interactive features, multiple endings, more characters, and the main character feels more realistic. All in all, it's an enjoyable and emotional story full of ups and downs in relationships. Not only romantic relationships, but friendships too. And that, I think, is the best part of this game. Mat is the MVP of the story! I doubted his intentions after the talk with Emily (although I still stood up for him) but later he proved me wrong and I felt really at fault. And the way he listened and helped me at the end, his iconic CHOICE words... I really wish, especially as a girl, that there was a way for him to become the main love interest. Because although I loved Evelyn in the first chapters, I was really dissapointed with the way she handled the situation in the last chapter. Mat was the only loyal friend to me. 

So I did like the game and recommend it, but many comments before mine noticed the right thing - each part of the series is like a copy of the previous part. The devs change the smallest things, like visuals, but the story, choices, outcomes and conversations stay the same. Expecially the setting and plot. It's like playing the same story in a different wrapping. You would lose nothing if you skip the first two parts and play just this one.

105165047.review:
I really like this game. It doesn't rely on cutting edge graphics or sound, but it does a great job of drawing you into the story.

Using an interface called "Facenook" which is just one typo away, it brings back those early days when the real thing was new and fresh and not the festering dumpster-fire that it is today. I stopped using the real "Facenook" almost 10 years ago, deleted all my posts and just keep it for the random friend that might send me a message. And you know what . . . I don't miss it at all. I still keep in touch with my close friends via texts. Same as "Facenook" circa 2008 but without all the added drama of seeing some friend of a friend repost the ginormous Cinnabon they just got at the food court and the multitude of meaningless and trite posts about whatever "cause du jour" that everyone is enraged about. Enough ranting.

This game has a kind of nostalgia that brings out memories of emotions and situations that I had forgotten -- possibly buried for good reason, but still worthy of revisiting. "Reliving" some of those with the benefit of the passing of time and a more mature perspective makes for an interesting game.

During the time I play, I try to mentally put myself into the same mental age and mindset of the characters. I sort of create a filter that keeps away the cynicism and eyerolling that I otherwise might do if I viewed it from a present-day perspective.

The game's simple interface is just as easy as it would have been back in the day. I like that there are links that will actually open up mock pages that look like they are from 2008ish and still have working links to actual YouTube videos from that time (although they have changed the name to something not unlike YouTube, the videos are actually from YouTube.

I don't want to give away the plot and the twists, of course, so no spoilers. The story itself starts out simple with your main character (who you can name as yourself or use any other name you like.) The main character is a male about age 15 who has just made the jump from AOL (You've got Mail!) to "Facenook" and created a brand new account.

From there, you are contacted by your best buddy (via the chat) and can choose from 3 predetermined responses to reply. (You actually still need to press keys to get the messages to print in the chat, but the game will print out the preset text. (You can just hold the spacebar if you like and watch the conversation magically appear).

At that point, the choices you make and the way you respond to the characters in the game affect how the game plays out. There aren't a multitude of outcomes, but enough that you'll enjoy playing through more than once so you can see all the possible outcomes.

It's a dark game that drips with adolescent angst, and even if you don't identify precisely with the main character, it's worth "suspending disbelief" and putting yourself in his shoes.

For me, it was easy enough because I lived through those adolescent angsty times and so several places during the story were familiar enough that it was eery. It's an everyman story for people who lived during that time, but it will also work for just about anyone who can remember what it was like to be an adolescent where you were driven by indecision, hormones, and the torrent of emotions that happen at that age, where even the smallest "crisis" seems like a life or death situation.

I'd recommend this for people who are older than the main characters and not for anyone who is currently under the age of 16 simply because it's meant to be a retrospective and unless your ultra-prodigious, you may not be able to grasp the message of the game. I think that it could also just be boring for present-day teens because it doesn't have the same glitz and glamour and polish of today's internet. But if you want a little glimpse into what life might have been like for your parents who were teens in the 2000s, then it might be of interest.

If you like a good story, with dark undertones and some surprises, then this is a great game. It's even good for a trip down memory lane and will either have you remembering your own past as long as you can mentally project back to when you were that age. Otherwise, you'll just eyeroll in frustration.

Let the game carry you into its world, and its story and you won't regret.

104768946.review:
[h1]Teen Heartbreak Simulator 3[/h1]
[i]well, kind of
not entirely[/i]

It was [i]January 2018[/i]. I just finished the first semester of my freshman year at the university and was done with the New Year festivities. Still somewhat anxious and depressed because of new environment and the death of one of my favourite singers of all time half a year prior, I was scrolling through YouTube to find myself something comforting. And I found a bit dated walkthrough (by Jacksepticeye) of this minimalistic, yet very cute game called [b]Emily is Away[/b] (2015). It proposed a trip to the internet of the past, to [b]good old times[/b], when social media wasn't that big of a thing and people used pretty simple AOL messengers for communication. Truth be told, back in 2008-2009 I used different kinds of chats, but despite that this game still somehow managed to make me feel [b]nostalgic[/b] and appreciative [i][of something that I never really experienced before][/i]. Although, behind that cute retro-aesthetic, a very sad story was hidden - a story about friendship and youth love, friendzone and [b]broken heart[/b]; a story about growing up and understanding that life isn't fairytale - people come and they go. And that's a pretty [b]bitter truth[/b] of life.

After playing through it, I wouldn't say that my spirits were lifted, quite contrary. But I definitely adored the [b]vision[/b] and [b]themes[/b] it went for, so when I realised that this game had a sequel - I immediately bought it and 100%-ed in a matter of few hours. [b]Emily is Away Too[/b] (2017) was a more expanded and interactive version of its predecessor, which gave players more features and whole two routes with different endings. Story wasn't completely linear and the essential aspect of [b]"parting ways"[/b] became avoidable, as long as you made the right choices and weren't being a two-faced dingus. With amazing nostalgic aesthetic, this game gave you a chance to make things right from the get-go, while still sticking to the characters and the world, created by [i]Mr. Seeley[/i] in the first game. Needless to say, I was [i]extremely[/i] stoked when the third game in the series got announced.

[hr][/hr]

And after three years of waiting, we come to this particular game.

So.

[b]Emily is Away <3[/b] (2021), similar to previous part, is not a direct sequel per se. It's more of a [b]reimagining[/b] of the story told before, but with fresh coat of paint and different outcomes. An [b]alternate universe[/b], if you will. Those, who already played [i]Emily is Away Too[/i], won't have hard time recognizing [b]Emily[/b] and [b]Evelyn[/b] [i][player's two possible romantic interests][/i], [b]Matt[/b] and [b]Kelly[/b] [i][previously mostly background characters][/i], [b]Jeff[/b] and [b]Steve[/b] [i][previously "ex-boyfriend" material][/i]. Well, here some of their roles have changed up a bit. For example, Matt is now your best buddy (who will be the one introducting you to the game), while Jeff and Steve turn from "bad memories of the past" to "possible future danger". As the game's description says, [i]AIM is pretty much dead[/i] in this version, so this game will take place in the [b]Facenook[/b] [[i]which previously served as an additional site not much used by player][/i].

The [b]features[/b] don't feel as prevalent as you can't really customize your preferences outside of chatting. And interaction with your personal browser in order to visit game's sites isn't anything new. Besides, the [b]plot[/b] is pretty similar to that of second game and structured in the very same way, despite it having some core differences. The story itself is quite [b][u]cyclical[/u][/b], which is ironic, and just like in the first game you are pretty much [b]doomed[/b] for a gut punch (at least first time playing). The problem is - game doesn't have that good of a replayability as events don't change one bit from route to route and the only dissimilarities between them are purely visual (like, different pictures and names). Otherwise, [b]aesthetics[/b] and whole tone are still as good as in previous two games, so if you are into nostalgic feel like that - it's a [b]worthwile catch[/b].

What this game has that previous ones don't is probably a direct opinion of a third person. Whereas in first and second ones you'd have your opinion and opinion of a girl you're talking to, here you also get a perspective of your friend, who is outside of your romantic relationships and can share observations you would otherwise miss. I'd say overall [i]Matthey Gursky[/i] is the best character here as he is the only real bro, who cements the core idea behind this installment, which is [b]"Strong friendship is more valuable than any romance could ever be"[/b]. Or, to put it simple - bros before hoes lol.

Oh, and also (!) in [i]"Secrets"[/i] section you can unlock a mini-game called [b]"Can you pet the dog?"[/b], which is the cutest thing ever and a pretty neat stress reliever.

104256769.review:
Emily is Away is not a game for people who aren't interested in 'choose your own adventure' type games. With multiple people to impress, a new girlfriend, graduation coming up and possibly moving away for college, it really slinks you back into a time and a place when choosing which party to go to on saturday night after work was the biggest problem you had.

This game really hits the nostalgia spot when it came to the layout of the old websites it references, the music each character shares with you, the slang in which both you and your friends casually use in conversation and just the general topics and themes of the game. Achievements include playing a mini game which is bootleg version of Farmville, and even being Rickrolled.

I was genuinely invested in these characters and story, their petty drama exhausted me to the point where I would finish a session and then go lay down because it felt like their problems really were my problem by association. These characters are written as if they are actually real, its hard to believe it's just a game, as I often felt 'I've been here before'.

The game made me laugh, kept me interested and absolutely broke my f-ing heart. My in-game girlfriend broke up with me, cheated on me (probably) and then sent me a song that was already a sad song I listen to in real life, which made me cry harder.

Can't wait to play the sequel and do it all again.

101573917.review:
Yet another one-up in the [i]Emily is Away[/i] series, this one now moves to senior year of high school and preparing for college, with the rise of Facebook (parodied here as "Facenook").

This game is the longest in the group so far and is the most in-depth, as you can jump around on people's profiles, look at their posts, see changes in music and other things over time, jump onto the parody of YouTube (like in the second game), etc. There are also parodies of other websites at the time, especially with a lot of Easter eggs.

Emily and Evelyn are here again, but it's disconnected from the second game, and you also talk to more people this time, including your personal best friend named Mat.

Simply put, I'm recommending it for the same reason as the previous two games: it emulates the internet culture very well.

But where the second game improved with its "story" for your character, this game pulls the rug out from under you in a bad way: [spoiler]The second game allowed you to have a good or bad ending based on your conversations, whereas this game guarantees a bad ending first time around. You are forced to make a couple of choices which results in one of the girls to drift away across the school year. Then, by the end of the school year, the girl you are closer to will essentially stop being with you in a largely counter-intuitive situation, regardless of what you do. Either she will cheat on you, or she will say you are not a trusting person; either way, you lose, and the only person left by the end is your friend Mat to help you out. If you want a "happy" ending, you need to play the game a second time and choose the other girl.[/spoiler]

So I can definitely see the above ruining things for people. But again, I played this for the style primarily, and that's where it succeeds.
